Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2008 12:45AM - edited Feb 9, 2008 03:42AM by angelonmyshoulder My oncologist said a lot of the problems with hand/foot is that the dose is too high.  I have lung mets she is starting me off at 500 mg. two pills morning and night for 14 days then 7 days off.  Two oncologists recommended that dose....FYI  For a total of 2000 a day.
Posts.Title: Fellow Xelodians please read Watson sueco

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2008 07:04PM - edited Feb 16, 2008 10:39AM by angelonmyshoulder That is wonderful news Katie!  I am moving to the planet of xeloda on the 14th.  Having orientation on the 13th to know what to be on the lookout for on the planet of xeloda. I think I might like like there for two week healing vacations!  I will think of it as being at a spa.  Lots of hand and foot massages with thick creams! Your wonderful report gives us all optimism and hope. Hugs, Wendy
Posts.Title: Fellow Xelodians please read Watson sueco

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2008 03:58PM - edited Feb 21, 2008 10:44PM by angelonmyshoulder Yes, I was told wine in moderation was okay.  I was told be careful drinking the hard stuff, along with spicy foods,  to prevent mouth sores .  Strictly for prevention.   Here I am in the Florida Keys and being told to stay out of the sun.   I am supposed to wear a big hat and lather on the sunscreen.    Taking 250 mgs (per doctor) of B6 per day to prevent HFS.  Moisturizing hands and feet often--recommended by doctor Udderly Smooth but not Udderly Balm, Lindi lotion and a few other ones.  Day 2 on xeloda it's munching away.... Hugs
Posts.Title: Fellow Xelodians please read Watson sueco

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2008 12:40AM - edited Feb 9, 2008 03:44AM by angelonmyshoulder Hello fellow Xelodians and Arimidexians! Thanks for the laugh!!  Great way to start the day! I am starting xeloda on February 13th too.    I have to take an hour long class on xeloda before they dispense the pills.  The main thing she said to look out for was pain in my hands or feet and to call her immediately if I experience any. Now I am concerned about nausea. Will have to research that a bit more.  What did you take for it?  Any premedication to prevent it or just for breakthrough nausea....like ativan or compazine? This is such a fantastic site.  You are all so wonderful!  My oncologist is recommending I go back on Arimidex too--even though I am ER-neg. She said it kept the cancer away for two years and has seen that happen in other women who are negative. I was weakly positive for estrogen in 2004 14%.

Your fellow Xelodian,

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2008 11:28PM angelonmyshoulder wrote: Much gratitude to everyone who has replied to my message.  I just woke up (the fear was starting) and saw the e-mails from all of you.  It was very comforting to read them--the fear is dissipating.  I had no hope nor encouragement from my doctor today.  You have all given me hope and encouragement.  I have the braca1 gene mutation and am triple negative.  Best wishes to all of you. Thank you.

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2008 09:03AM angelonmyshoulder wrote: Hi Mitzi, Sounds like it could very well be a local reccurence.  Glad the cytology report came back neg. for cancer.  I have had nodules on and off and they just disappear.  I had some caused by my weekly taxotere in 2004 along with pleural effusions.  That can be a side effect from chemo.  I have two nodules now but my oncologist feels they are not related to the lung mets. In my case, the pleural effusions were caused by my mediport failing.... It sounds like your sister is doing well.  She is lucky to have you as an advocate and for support. Best of luck to your sister.  We are all here for you and her.

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2008 12:32AM angelonmyshoulder wrote: Hi Young,  Just wanted to let you know that I met with Dr. Vogel's associate yesterday, Dr. Mahtani!  She is so smart, compassionate, caring-- I could go on and on. She spent a lot of time with my husband and me. Dr. Vogel is lecturing out of the country, on recurrent triple negative breast cancer with lung mets (which is what I have). She  will contact him regarding my case. I am encouraged by what I heard today.  I have finally found a compassionate and thorough oncologist.  Thank you for referring Dr Vogel/Mahtani to me on this site.  My fear is easing now that I know someone competent is in control. Her/his nurse is wonderful too.  She was great on the phone with me before we had even met; and in person her smile was uplifting.  With gratitude--

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2008 04:35AM angelonmyshoulder wrote: I love my port too. Wouldn't be without it.  The pain lasted about a week.  It shouldn't hurt when you turn your head.  Be sure and ask about the pain if it continues. They can do a portogram if you continue to have problems with it to be sure it's in the right position.
Posts.Title: Decided to get a port Analemma shafali
